title: Southern rail users face more strikes as drivers reject Aslef-backed deal | Business | The Guardian
text:
Southern Southern rail users face more strikes as drivers reject Aslef-backed deal 
Drivers vote against agreement that would have accepted rail firm’s plans for more driver-only operation of trains A Southern train. Photograph: Philip Toscano/PA View more sharing options Thursday 16 February 2017 13.31 GMT Last modified on Thursday 16 February 2017 13.33 GMT 
Drivers for Southern have rejected a deal negotiated between the Aslef union and their employer, reigniting a long-running dispute that has frequently stranded hundreds of thousands of commuters. 
The drivers voted by 54%-46% against a deal that offered limited assurances on rostering a second, safety trained crew member in return for accepting Southern’s government-led plans for more driver-only operation. 
More strikes are likely to follow once the union’s executive has decided on the next course of action. 
Mick Whelan, general secretary of Aslef, said: “We understand and support the decision arrived at democratically by our members and will now work to deliver a resolution in line with their expectations.” 
The proposed deal was agreed by Aslef negotiators and Southern on 2 February after two weeks of talks brokered by the TUC, and was heralded as signalling the end of a dispute that had contributed to making Southern, run by Govia Thameslink Railway, the worst performing train operator in Britain. 
Many drivers were angered when the terms of the deal were revealed in the following days, including concessions on a key principle that a train can run in certain circumstances with only a driver on board. 
But drivers had lost significant pay both through a series of strikes and an overtime ban from early December that had closed branch lines and severely disrupted services, and Aslef believed most would accept the deal its leadership had recommended. 
The RMT union, which has been at the forefront of the dispute with Southern since last April, representing the conductors who were downgraded to onboard supervisors, was not involved in the talks at the TUC and denounced the agreement as a “historic betrayal” . 
Talks between Southern and the RMT at Acas this week foundered on the first day, and the union has called another 24-hour strike for next Wednesday, 22 February. Southern says it expects to run around three-quarters of its usual timetable during the strike. 
The row over the roles and responsibilities of train crew is likely to be replicated across other parts of Britain’s railway. A ballot for strikes on the Northern network began on Thursday over what the RMT described as a “failure to give assurances on guards”, with new trains expected from 2018 that could be operated by drivers alone. 
Merseyrail plans to operate trains without guards from 2020, although it has promised to redeploy staff. The government is encouraging bidders for future franchises, including South West, to come up with plans to phase out guards, with new trains designed to be operated by drivers alone.
